newsitem.title: INDIA: India 97/98 export growth seen at about 20 pct.
newsitem.headline: India 97/98 export growth seen at about 20 pct.

text.p: Indian Commerce Minister Bolla Buli Ramaiah was quoted on Saturday as saying the government expects exports to grow by about 20 percent in 1997/98 (April-March) over the current fiscal year.

"We welcome the budget for 1997/98 as it incorporates the proposals made on behalf of the exporting community in our pre-budget memorandum," the Press Trust of India (PTI) quoted Ramaiah as saying in an interview.
Between April 1996 and January 1997, exports increased by 6.19 percent over the same 10-month period ended in January 1996, rising to $27.07 billion.
Ramaiah was quoted as saying a proposal in the 1997/98 budget to exempt export profits from the minimum alternate tax (MAT) on companies would spur foreign sales.
PTI quoted him as saying the budget would also bring down the cost of credit, which he called essential to the exporting community.
The commerce minister noted that exports rose by 8.77 percent in January to $2.84 billion, after declining in December, and said he hoped the upward growth trend would continue in February and March.
